reviewText:
Broken, lacking depth, arcade rubbish. The words that spring to mind having now played 8 hrs since launch. That the developers have labelled this a simulation and imagine it is worthy as a release candidate beggars belief.

Pick one of 4 rig types that you are limited to carrying when you are fishing, pick one of four baits that you are limited to carrying and that's your terminal tackle sorted, seriously? Where do I adjust boilie buoyancy, hair length, my shock leader, and link length, pick hook type and size independent of the chosen rig. Where are the method feeders, carp poles, marker floats, bait boats, baiting sticks, feeder rods. Where are the oils for soaking boilie's, the pva stringers and bags, and the selection of groundbaits and particles for the spod rod. Why the hell are worms, luncheon meat, casters and maggots awol in a fishing game that features roach bream, tench and carp. Where is the window dressing such as alternate clothing, bivvies, bite alarms, landing nets, et al. Everything I would expect to see at launch from a title labelled an accurate simulation of European Fishing.

Then there are the game mechanics that are present but not working correctly, even the basics such as fish control and landing glitch frequently, fish that run for 20 meters under the bank, line retrieval that bears no relationship to what I am actually doing or seeing, fish that become stuck under the tip of my rod, fish ai that is unaffected by wind direction, then there are the constant stream of bites, how I wish that fishing for carp and cats was so easy irl.

I could go on but if you do not have a clear picture of this title yet, there is little point.

It clearly has potential, graphically it looks good, but as a simulation of angling it stinks, as a release candidate it stinks, it is just not good enough; at best it is a shallow, broken, arcade game.

reviewText:
Cons:
- The game looks pretty bad. They clearly spent a lot of time on their foliage, but for a game that's all about staring at water for hours on end, their water effects are absolutely terrible.
- - There are no water physics at all. Even when you are reeling in a fish the water just remains static and boring.
- - Even on Ultra the water doesn't reflect the sky or surroundings.
- - You really can't see into the water. They don't have fish swimming around the bottom. They don't really have visible weeds or anything like that. It's just murky brown blandness.
- Lack of variety. You are basically limited to several different types of carp, and one or two lakes also have catfish.
- The net mechanic. It's awkward, it hurts the flow of the game, and I suspect the mechanic was mostly added to avoid needing physics for the fish.
- There are no physics for the fish. You can't pull the fish out of the water with the rod while you're reeling it in. You never see the fish satisfyingly thrashing in the water, on the hook, or in your hands.
- You can't get your line caught in a tree.

Pros:
- The casting physics are a fun novelty until the rest of the game ruins the experience for you.
- It's cheaper than a fishing license. Also you don't need to go outside.

The pictures and videos on the store page definitely make the game look better than it actually is. It's not the worst purchase I've ever made but I've already uninstalled it and probably won't ever be playing it again.

Early Access Review

[Early Access - Phase 5] UPDATE

YES! You finally have a sense of freedom in freedom fishing. Game mechanics feel good, though I feel like now I'm throwing so far I might hit mountains the far distance. I liked the triple spinning wheel bug as well, sadly it is going to be fixed.

[Early Access - Phase 3] UPDATE

What I like:
- Casting is a lot easier. I didn't find myself trying over and over again to get a goot shot like in phase 1, and I didn't have to move mymouse all across the table (mouse mat was sufficient :)).
- Improved visuals. Some of the things that annoyed me about the first release was some basic but unrealistic/immersion breaking visuals like a rope-thick line and a very wobbly fishing pole. These have been fixed now, at least to some extent. The line is pretty good, or perfect in terms of thickness now and the pole has just about the right stiffness to it. I still experience motor-boating and pole glitches kind of often, but the basics are a lot better.
- Character feedback. Another issue I had that has now been improved on is the characters feedback to the force of the fish and so on, when you are fishing. It is very pleasing, and I didn't find my self getting thrown off by the characters reactions this time - big +.
- New features. The fish variations are great and I managed to catch a few during my testing of the game. Leader boards are great. Adds a lot more to the game and actually makes it worthwhile to play the game in its current state. I didn't manage to go too far up the rankings but it was a lot more fun and exciting to catch something and see how far it will get you.

What I could see improved:
- The fish AI. It was a lot better than first time I played, but I still experienced fish going from 10-80yds in a matter of seconds when fishing from some spots (especially the little closed spot without a lot of room, had issues). The fish also seemed to not care about swimming through landscape as I frequently saw fish going directly throw rocks/trees and sometimes into the land/road/path on the other side of the lake.
- The force on the pole when having a hook is ok, but the line is not always acting accordingly. I frequently experienced a pole arced and bent like a bow, while the line acted as is if no force at all was being aplied to it.

What I didn't like:
- Reeling/catching fish seems to be bugged sometimes as I have found myself reeling in for a solid 10 minutes two times in a row at the same fishing spot without anything major happening to the yard indicator/other. I frequently feel like having no idea whats going on underneath the water. Like if I'm catching a fish and it's almost in reach (5-10ish)yds I'm just able to keep reeling in without anything happening. The line should be rather short at that point, but it feels like it's extended by 100 miles underneath the water. Also while reeling, at times when I was not able to pull the fish towards me (maybe extended the line underneath the water) I was still able to steer the fish to the left or right which makes no sense. While reeling I often wondered if the game had bugged out, if I was doing something totally wrong etc. Didn't feel very responsive.

I think the latest updates have been good and have improved the game in areas where improvement were needed, but some fundamentals are still flawed. Pleased with this update :)

-----------------------------------
[Early Access - Phase 1] ORIGINAL

I understand the game is in early access, but I just think it is lacking in too many aspects, and I think the developers should have waited a bit before releasing it to the public and accepting your money.

What you get to see in this early access is basically a few tutorials and trials, so you can get a feel for how the game and the mechanics are going to be implemented. This is fine, it is content-wise what they claimed it to be. I would be satisfied with this amount of content, if it wasn't because of the bare basics of the game not being very well implemented at all yet. For a dedicated fishing simulator, it doesn't do a very good job at simulating what real fishing feels like. On top of that the mechanics felt clunky, the visuals didn't feel right and the main point of the game (fishing) felt really awkward, unreal and unresponsive.

Problems with the visuals:
- The fishing line looks thicker than the pole itself, and I know it has to be easy to see on screen but there has to be a better way. The line also seems a lot heavier than an actual line (which is as light as a snowflake flowing in the wind), when you look at how it reacts with the physics currently in the game.
- The fishing pole looks way too rubbery/elastic compared to a real pole. Very wobly :). Like if you shake your hand a bit, it might go all bananes.
- The tension on the fishing line is the worst part about the visual issues. Very immersion breaking. When I have a fish on the line, the string tension is very unrealistic. It doesn't matter if the fish is 40 yards away or 10 yards, if I'm reeling in or being idle, the string looks all the same. I get no real feel for how far away the fish is, how hard it is pulling and so on - other than the numbers I see on the screen. I found this to be very immersion breaking, it didn't feel at all like I was having a hook!

Problems with the game (fishing).
- When I'm reeling in I have no idea what is going on underneath the water. Sometimes I was reeling in for a long long while, but the yard indicator stayed the same, and there was no other visual feedback. I didn't know if the game had glitched out and my reeling didn't do anything, or if the fish had managed to extend my line by another 100 yeards underneath the water for me to reel in afterwards. I think it would be nice to get some sort of idea of how long your line is, and not just how far away the fish is. Because this just felt so weird when I couldn't feel the force in my pole, and just stood there reeling in for minutes from a minor hook.
- The fish (1 kind in this early alpha) is very athletic, it goes from one end of the lake and back in a matter of seconds. It does this for a while, then suddenly stops. Like it spend all of its energy traveling so fast from one end of the lake to the other and then suddenly colapses. It also bites the hook very frequently, so the food must me scarse around this lake. :)
- As mentioned earlier you get almost no visual feedback or cues from the fishing pole, the string or the fishing guy. When you get a hook the pole, string, and the guy - they all just act as if there was no force pulling in the other end of the line. In contrast to this, the fish is going crazy underneath the water as I mentioned earlier. It just feels so unrealistic and weird. This would be okay as a side game in GTA or something like that, but this coming from a dedicated fishing simulator was disappointing.

Problems with the controls:
- Something feels really awkward about the controls, I have a hard time pointing out exactly what is causing this.
- I think one part is the mouse sensitivity. You turn very slowly while the pole is very wobly and when you throw the line out into the water I almost have to move my hand all across the desk to get a good shot.
- The throwing part does not feel consistent. Sometimes I get a really nice shot, but the next time I do the eactly same movement (with minor differences ofc), the bait may end up only 11 yards away and in another direction. It just didn't feel right.

All in all, I think the basic features should have been better implemented when releasing a paid early access of a dedicated fishing game with this amount of content. I don't see a point for anyone to get it yet, UNLESS you are very interested in fishing and can't wait to get a glimpse of what this new game will look like.

The menu screen is barebone and only is navigated by keyboard. The options are barebone with only having settings for mouse sensitivity, audio levels, and Graphics detail (low,med,high,ultra), resolution with being able to select fullscreen, window or borderless window. Mechanics-

Sometimes even while releasing the line it will shoot forward then bounce back oddly. When the line is in the water it is pretty smooth sailing, and reeling in the fish is fun. I just wish upon landing the fish it would at least make up some numbers for you so you can keep trying for something other then landing another generic fish. Also be aware that the current plans is to only add in carp til a much later date.

***

Lowdown- As of this review the game is in very early alpha, but looks promising. With a great intro price of $7 ( which is said to increase as development continues), its a good time to buy to support pretty much the only modern realistic fishing game on steam or PC pretty much. This is only reason I recommend this game at this stage

Firstly the closest I have ever come to actually fishing, is this game! I knew nothing of fishing or it's intricacies until I ventured onto this game. My Husband and Son have been plaing this game for a while, and to be honest, it is great viewing as well as playing.
But I wanted to have a go myself and see just what all the fishy fun was about. Cue my guy, Wilhelm. Wilhelm is going great guns. He has 3 rods; Kenny 'Fishing' Powers, Ray Bream-ero and Doug Heffer-Carp. The delight in pulling in a fish that takes a while to land is thrilling and just so satifying. An Acheivement that is as unexpected as it is awesome.

So about the game; well, go through the tutorial or Acadamy to learn the basics- if you know nothing as I did then this is the  place where your fishy education begins. Then feel free to go and complete the challenges you have unlocked, or free fishing and just enjoy the game's beautiful ambience. The graphics, the fish detail, the weather, the sounds within this game are just fantastic. Immersive and peaceful. The gentle plopping of fish as they leap out of the water, or the sound of the wind as it begins to rise (shadow detail also shows the tree shadows moving in the wind) or the pitter patter of rain. I just simply love playing.

There are levels to go up, a skill tree for tackle and bait. Earning Tackle Points as you catch fish, complete challenges and finish tournaments (the latter has either a live daily match or in game AI tournaments) means that you can develop your fisher-person to be the best in every field or go for one particular area of expertise.

There is nothing quite like landing your first big carp, or first fish, but the ultimate (next to Boss Fish) is catching a HUGE Catfish!!!!

Notes on gameplay: -

* Have patience. Learn the tension gradients that are applicable to your tackle- losing a fish that you have spent 5 minutes reeling in only for it to get away can be gutting. Learn your rod's capability

* Equip your net at 4yrds or less to get the instant land- anything above 4 and you wont be able to manouvre the net to catch the fish.

* Screenshots are addictive- But awesome to show off those catches that made you feel proud. Please do take a peek at mine if you would like to see the look of the fish.

* Character choice is limited- but there is no need to have a full on customisation option when all you see mostly is the back of your character.

* Learn about the rigs, the best bait for that rig and go fishing where the fish you want to catch hang out.

* Read the Boss Fish Menu and descriptions they are awesome

* Don't be disheartened Rome wasn't built in a day and neither is the best tacklebox- take your time and have fun with the game.

* Make as many fish related puns as you can- this is a source of never ending amusment. Life is but a Bream :-)

* Slow life down for an hour! Take the small joy of a days fishing and be at peace. No traffic, no bosses moaning, no stress- just one rod at a time, one fishy at a time

Enjoy and 'Carp-i' Diem ;-P

reviewText:
I think most of the negative reviews come from bad experiences pre- and early launch. A lot of the bugs and issues have been fixed now, so I can definetely recommend this game. It may not be the best fishing simulator, but it is still an enjoyable game.
A few positive points:
- An in-game shop with a very extensive set of possibilities for your tackle boxes: reels, rods, lines, hooks, baits...
- Several fish species: multiple carp species, catfish, bream, roach...
- different bed types: silt, gravel and weed. You have to keep this in mind when choosing your hooks and bait.
- Enjoyable and relaxing ambient sound.
- The thrill to keep fishing to get to the top of the leaderboards, and/or set a personal best. There's also your profile with statistics and fish species and bosses you have already/not caught. Each lake has its own unique bosses.
- There are also online tournaments, tutorials, AI competitions and minigames which all reward in-game currency and xp.
Negative points:
- A few graphical bugs.
- The time to wait for a fish to bite is sometimes too long.
- Some players find casting too hard. I find it easy (after a bit of practice).

In general this is a very good game, but for some people this may be too expensive because you can get bored soon.

reviewText:
A good enough concept; graphics are reasonably solid, equipment is diverse, and there are good sized fishing locales which can be roamed pretty freely. Cooperative play works well in my limited experience playing this way, however be aware that another player can stand literally on top of you, completelyt obscuring your view and making it almost impossible to see, and therein do, anything at all--something as ironic as it is nonsensical, given that another player is cannot, supposedly, fish the same spot as you concomitantly ('Pegged' areas become player unique territories once pegged by any single player). This just one example of how poor game design makes Euro fishing contravene its own intentions. And logic.

Euro Fishing is ultimately  rendered frustrating and not really worth playing owing to bugs, and some extremely poor mechanics--specifically the striking and netting features. Both are awkward, clunky,  drudgerous  and generally difficult to negotiate with a keyboard & mouse setup. With respect to the former,  you have to really slide backwards with your mouse very quickly (and quite excessively)  quite a distance to succesfully sink in a strike which may or may not bug out irregardless of line tension. It's not easy to get right, and Lag spikes compund this problem considerably.

The netting mechanic is, quite simply, spectacularly and singularly awful, and needs to be rebuilt from the ground up or done away with entirely. Because you cannot simueltaneously control your rod (with fish on) and the net at the same time, it is extremely difficult to orientate either so they allign, which is what you need to do in order to succesfully land a fish. What5 this tends to result in  ( along with many, many lost fish) is aa kind of rage-inspiring comedy of errors to the tune of:

Reel in fish a little closer to the bank. Pick up net. Fish takes out more line, making iut impossible to net fish.  Drop net. Reel in fish a little. Pick up net. Net not at correct angle in order to allign with fish. Drop net. Repeat x3. Get frustrated. Attempt to skulldrag fish in as close to the bank as possible in order to compensate for abysmal ( and entirely not sensitive enough) netting mechanic. Drag suddenly gooes from not tight enough to too tight. Line breaks, lose fish.

And over and over ad nauseam.

Perhaps the system is easier to negotiate with a controller. I have not played Euro fishing this way.
In any case, the game feels rushed, malformed , and  compared to something like fishing planet, is more annoying than it is enjoyable--additionally, there's not enough that's great about about it to allow one to look past its considerable and multivariate problems.

Score:
3/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

With Phase 6, I think it's even clearer than before that this game is going to turn out to be something good. It started out as a very solid, albeit bare, fishing game, but with every update features are added, and mechanics are dialed in some more. The team seems to be listening intently and working hard to put out as much win in every update as they possibly can.

This update brings a working multiplayer mode, which consists of the training lake (only) and up to 4 (iirc) other people fishing. There is a (half-working atm) chat function that lets players on a lake share tips and brag about big catches, which is very cool (if I see someone landing many fish, I tend to ask what bait they're using). Using chat while on a peg is problematic, though, due to the hotkeys for keyboard controls not being disabled while focus is on the chat box. My whole peg has been closed many times because I tried to chat, heh. The chat box also has a bad habit of ignoring sentences. Other than that, multiplayer is definitely working and enjoyable.

The quality of the fishing experience gets better with every update (imo), and the team behind it stay on the forums, getting feedback and making changes based on what they see and hear. Force feedback on a 360 controller is much improved, and the controls, for the most part, make sense. However, general consensus is that a mouse gives much better control of power for accurate casting.

You carry a tackle box and up to three fishing rods, and gain new gear by spending money earned from catching fish. Lake bed conditions and other factors make the careful choosing of bait and gear an important part of the process, as well as knowing a good spot or two. One can have 3 fishing rods baited and in the water at a time, and alarms on each rod (audible + light) let you know if something is nibbling and running with anything.

There are occasional bugs (flying fish, SPOD-arm until restart), but nothing too bad. After the features get hammered out better I am sure that the few there are will be dealt with accordingly.

If you like fishing and video games, this is a pretty safe bet. Just don't expect it to be a polished experience at this time.

Where is this game going on PC ?

At the time of posting this there are 12 players in game with a 24 hour peak of 22 players. The average game time over the last 2 weeks for all players is just 8 mins and the highest peak was 87 players in game 3 months ago.

I hammered play hours into this game earlier this year and was very optimistic that the ideal carp/coarse fishing game was on it's way but I'm now of the opinion that whilst the community might differ in their opinion of the quality of the beta versions being offered up via Steam, the developers are now just using the PC players to bench test" the gameplay on the version they plan to push out on console.

Looking at those stats (8 mins average play over 2 weeks!) this far down the line I can't come to any other conclusion. The game is losing players and yet I still sense no urgency on the part of the developers to address those issues that the community is constantly offering up as constructive feedback relating to their gameplay experience.

I am not being negative for the sake of it but the game appears to be going backwards in overall quality
date:
aside the fact that additional content is being added in beta versions.

The Beta versions I've tried appear to contain many more "glitches" and bugs than the Alpha version that players enjoyed throughout the summer!

All stats were taken from Steam's own database and if it transpires that those figures don't include ongoing "beta" versions then I still think we should be nearer a finished and more polished version for the PC than we are now.

I originally gave this game an ethusiastic thumbs up earlier this year but I regret that I can't continue to recommend it in its current state.  Even Early Access appears to have been withdrawn from the Steam Store with a final "Retail Release" being further delayed.

Very disappointed overall given the game once appeared to have so much promise.

reviewText:
I really enjoyed Cabela's Big Game Hunter, and tried Eurofishing looking for the wilderness ambient and fishing/hunting strategy. I am enjoying the game, but I must say that casting by moving the mouse and clicking the right button at the same time is messy and inpractical. Anyway, by adjusting the mouse sensibility (middle position) I found that it is a lot easier. Still, I wish it could be done in other way.

Lakes are great. Each one with its unical features, including boss fishes. I hope they will add some more lakes in the future. Those available are located in various countrys, and tough the lakes themselves are fictional, they strongly resembles the real lakes of those areas.

My main complain is that you don't need much strategy for fishing. I mean, you mainly search for a nice peg, or go stalking. Fish move through the day from one area to another. But there's nothing that you can do to catch a certain species (well, except for the kind of bait you use), or going for real big fish or lake bosses . I would like the game to be more rewarding for the patient, strategic player, but devs tend to make this games more rewarding for begginers, in hope that they won't put down it due to initial boredom. The devs had stated that they are adding float fishing for free in the next weeks, so I hope the game will grow and get better. The store is a bit small, I would like to have more items to buy, including clothes, customized equipment, and so.

Oh, and Multiplayer is ok, but is not my thing.

Last, but not least: I feel that the game is not very optimized. It won't run fluent in the typical laptop. My GeForce 840N doesn't handle it very nicely. You better check the requirements.

As a clonclusion... a very nice game, **if you like these kind of games**. I am in hope that the game community will grow and that the devs will create exciting new scenarios and items.
